simulation package¶

Submodules¶

simulation.cpu module¶

CPU Driven simulation of a toy star

simulation.cpu.get_acc(pos: ndarray, vel: ndarray, mass: float, h: float, k: float, poly_index: int, lmbda: float, nu: float) → ndarray[source]¶

Calculate the acceleration on each SPH particle

Parameters¶

pos (np.ndarray): is an N x 3 matrix of positions vel (np.ndarray): is an N x 3 matrix of velocities mass (float): is the particle mass h (float): is the smoothing length k (float): equation of state constant poly_index (int): polytropic index lmbda external (float): force constant nu (float): viscosity

Returns¶

a (np.ndarray): is N x 3 matrix of accelerations

simulation.cpu.get_density(r: ndarray, mass: float, h: float, rexp: ndarray) → ndarray[source]¶

Get Density at sampling loctions from SPH particle distribution

Parameters¶

r (np.ndarray): is an M x 3 matrix of sampling locations mass (float): is the particle mass h (float): is the smoothing length rexp (np.ndarray): is the precomputed exp(-(x^2 + y^2 + z^2) / (h^2))

Returns¶

rho (np.ndarray): is M x 1 vector of densities

simulation.cpu.get_pairwise_separations(ri: ndarray, rj: ndarray) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, ndarray][source]¶

Get pairwise desprations between 2 sets of coordinates

Parameters¶

ri (np.ndarray): is an M x 3 matrix of positions rj (np.ndarray): is an N x 3 matrix of positions

Returns¶

dx, dy, dz (np.ndarray, np.ndarray, np.ndarray): are M x N matrices of separations

simulation.cpu.get_pressure(rho: ndarray, k: float, n: int) → ndarray[source]¶

Equation of State

Parameters¶

rho (np.ndarray): vector of densities k (float): equation of state constant n (int): polytropic index

Returns¶

p (np.ndarray): pressure

simulation.cpu.grad_w(x: ndarray, y: ndarray, z: ndarray, h: float, rexp: ndarray) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, ndarray][source]¶

Gradient of the Gausssian Smoothing kernel (3D)

Parameters¶

x (np.ndarray): a vector/matrix of x positions y (np.ndarray): a vector/matrix of y positions z (np.ndarray): a vector/matrix of z positions h (float): the smoothing length rexp (np.ndarray): is the precomputed exp(-(x^2 + y^2 + z^2) / (h^2))

Returns¶

wx, wy, wz (np.ndarray, np.ndarray, np.ndarray): the evaluated gradient

simulation.cpu.main() → None[source]¶
simulation.cpu.r_exp(x: ndarray, y: ndarray, z: ndarray, h: float) → ndarray[source]¶

Cached function for a common operation

Parameters¶

x (np.ndarray): a vector/matrix of x positions y (np.ndarray): a vector/matrix of y positions z (np.ndarray): a vector/matrix of z positions h (float): the smoothing length

Returns¶

(np.ndarray): exp(-(x^2 + y^2 + z^2) / (h^2))

simulation.cpu.sim(plot: bool, n: int = 5000, time_end: float = 100, plot_2d: bool = False, plot_real_time: bool = True) → None[source]¶

SPH simulation

Parameters¶

plot: (bool): Plot a simulation of a star if true n (int): Number of particles time_end (float): How long the simulation should run plot_2d (bool): If true, plot 2d. If false, plot 3d plot_real_time (bool): Plot a simulation of a star in real time if true,

if False, just show the last time step

Returns None ——-

simulation.cpu.w(h: float, rexp: ndarray) → ndarray[source]¶

Gausssian Smoothing kernel (3D) (w is the evaluated smoothing function)

Parameters¶

h (float): the smoothing length rexp (np.ndarray): is the precomputed exp(-(x^2 + y^2 + z^2) / (h^2))

Returns: np.ndarray

simulation.gpu module¶

GPU Driven simulation of a toy star using CUDA

simulation.gpu.sim(plot: bool, n: int = 5000, time_end: float = 100, plot_2d: bool = False, plot_real_time: bool = True) → None[source]¶

SPH simulation

This operation consumes a lot of GPU memory, If you want to free gpu memory before or after this operation call mempool = cp.get_default_memory_pool() mempool.free_all_blocks()

Parameters¶

plot: (bool): Plot a simulation of a star if true n (int): Number of particles time_end (float): How long the simulation should run plot_2d (bool): If true, plot 2d. If false, plot 3d plot_real_time (bool): Plot a simulation of a star in real time if true,

if False, just show the last time step

Returns None ——-

simulation.gpu.w(h: float, rexp: ndarray) → ndarray[source]¶

Parameters¶

h (float): the smoothing length rexp (cp.ndarray): is the precomputed exp(-(x^2 + y^2 + z^2) / (h^2))

Returns: cp.ndarray

Calculate the acceleration on each SPH particle pos is an N x 3 matrix of positions vel is an N x 3 matrix of velocities m is the particle mass h is the smoothing length k equation of state constant n polytropic index lmbda external force constant nu viscosity a is N x 3 matrix of accelerations

SPH simulation

simulation.sph_test module¶

We want to make sure that the simulation does what it should even after our optimizations

We add a test case with the old implementation, and then ensures that the newer implementetation return the same value

We do this using the pytest framework

Note: We only need to test function getAcc, it should cover all the code that was changed

simulation.sph_test.test_get_acc() → None[source]¶

Test the new getAcc to ensure it returns the same result as the old getAcc function

Module contents¶

toy-star
